poems.title: At the edge
poems.content:
Somewhere in the savanah, it’s just us. Hunter and prey.
We move slowly, certain that the ground is unsteady.
The shifting wind leaning in anticipation, as if they had a dog in the fight.
A canopy of clouds assemble at the edge of our sight.
Songs were never meant to last this long
You replay the same memories, wishing there was an edit button
The lights wink at the window, like they’re tired of the dark
I watch the clock, but time won’t keep its hands to itself
Our cups aren’t empty, just full of tiny particles that forever fly
Still, we sit here, convinced that thinking machines aren’t magic

poems.title: the secret sauce
poems.content:
How do you talk like a poet
How ?
I have tried to solve this riddle, and,
I think there is room for growth
I start too many lines with “And”
Too many sentences with ”I”
So, it probably reads too cliche
When do I start to feel among
And have my pieces read like the
Authors I read their works on rattle.com
Or the many publications I’ve seen on X,
housing submissions that really intimidate
They have pages lined with text, full to the brim
Inflections in weird but strategic places
And it all rhymes in an uncommon way, where
The words do not end with the same sound
But the shoe just fits
You know what I mean?
Almost as if
they had a manual
That taught them how to cast spells
Without uttering a syllable
But with the strokes of their pen
Engraved on a digital screen in the wild
I wish I had this manual
And I could talk like a poet
Maybe I would do a better job at a cliffhanger

poems.title: One for them and one for me
poems.content:
I thought about what would be an eye catching piece for my WhatsApp story 
I manage to attract a few admirers there
They enjoy when I appear with a new piece
Out of the blue, with lengthy texts about love
Sometimes I wonder if they know the true stories behind what they read
Or they just get it
Well, what do I mean?
I mean, “they just get it”. They interpret as they wish
What they make of it is theirs to choose
From the moment its light met their eyes
And the neurons in their brain popped open with words
The words ceased to be mine
It became whatever story was told in that shiny corner of their head
From then on, the piece diverges
One for them and one for me
For them, the words draw a pattern on the sand
Its grains hit close to home
And it gets especially muddy when it rains
For me, the texts run in multiple directions
Like I do when playing football
Knowing the goal lies at both ends of the pitch
One for them and one for me.

poems.title: fingers
poems.content:
My fingers write so fast,
sometimes I feel like I’m left out,
merely observing the speed and joy with which words emerge—
sentences both flawed and flawless lining up.

Yet, eventually, I join the party
to smooth the edges,
remove misplaced lettrers,
and rewrite the statements borne of this euphoria.

I do not mind;
we do not mind,
for every piece,
whether polished or half-baked,
is ours to claim.

Together, we create,
pushing until meanings exhaust
and the plot dissolves like sweat stolen by cold air.

Still, we write,
drawing from what feels like endless pools of creativity.

If you’re still here,
reading this reckless exercise,
you have my gratitude.

No proofreading will follow;
this is a tribute to my fingers—
tireless, strong, and long—
the pen that was never titled,
the ink with which I write.

Or perhaps it’s my brain?
But let’s not lose ourselves in that debate.

Forgive me, reader,
for this is about nothing
anyone would want to read—
not even me, the writer.

Or is it my fingers,
who could never read?
